summary: A letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorney, Christian R. Everdell, to the U.S. Attorney's Office, complaining about delays and technical problems with the government's production of discovery materials to Maxwell while she is incarcerated at the MDC. The letter lists specific Bates number ranges of documents Maxwell cannot access.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell who authored the letter to the U.S. Attorney's Office, detailing problems with discovery production and access for his client.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the case 'United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell'. She is incarcerated at the MDC and is having difficulty accessing discovery materials provided by the government.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Issued the scheduling order (Dkt. 25) which set the deadline for initial non-electronic discovery production.

persons.name: Holly Pratesi
persons.context: An individual at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) who communicated about potential resolution of problems with audio and video file access for Maxwell.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Copied on the correspondence as part of Maxwell's legal defense team at Cohen & Gresser LLP.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Copied on the correspondence as part of Maxwell's legal defense team at Cohen & Gresser LLP.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Copied on the correspondence as part of Maxwell's legal defense team at Cohen & Gresser LLP.

persons.name: Ms. Comey
persons.context: A prosecutor at the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, addressed in the letter regarding discovery issues.

persons.name: Ms. Moe
persons.context: A prosecutor at the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, addressed in the letter regarding discovery issues.

persons.name: Ms. Pomerantz
persons.context: A prosecutor at the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, addressed in the letter regarding discovery issues.

connections.description: Everdell is writing as Maxwell's defense attorney to address issues with her access to discovery materials.
Everdell is corresponding with prosecutor Comey regarding procedural and technical issues in the case.
Cohen is part of Maxwell's legal defense team, as indicated by being copied on the correspondence.
Pagliuca is part of Maxwell's legal defense team, as indicated by being copied on the correspondence.
Menninger is part of Maxwell's legal defense team, as indicated by being copied on the correspondence.
Pratesi, an MDC staff member, communicated about technical issues affecting Maxwell's access to discovery files.

events.title: Discovery Production Deadline
events.description: Court-ordered deadline for the government to complete production of initial non-electronic discovery to the defense, as per Judge Nathan's scheduling order.

events.title: Late Discovery Delivery to Maxwell
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell received the third and final production of initial non-electronic discovery several days after the court-imposed deadline.

events.title: Upcoming Discovery Deadline
events.description: The date by which the government is expected to produce the remainder of the discovery, as referenced in the letter.

locations: United States Attorney's Office Southern District of New York, 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
Cohen & Gresser LLP, 800 Third Avenue, 21st Floor, New York, New York 10022
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team filed a formal complaint about the government's failure to meet court-ordered discovery deadlines and provide accessible files.
Maxwell, incarcerated at the MDC, could not open numerous listed documents and any audio or video files from the discovery production.
The discovery in question includes a substantial volume of material, with Bates numbers ranging from SDNY GM 00000001 to SDNY GM 00174966 for the initial non-electronic production.
The defense requested the government immediately reproduce all discovery on a new hard drive with appropriate software tools for Maxwell to review.
The letter reveals logistical and technical challenges in providing discovery to a high-profile detainee, potentially impacting her ability to prepare for trial.
